abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Water Supply
            Technical Assistance and Rehabilitation Project for Guyana
            were as follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. The lessons learned
            indicate that The success of the project depended in great
            part on the ability of the executing agency, Guyana Water
            Authority (GUYWA), to be able to implement the designated
            investment program, including meeting the conditionalities
            specified. The lack of donor coordination in the water
            sector was actually impeding progress. There were
            uncoordinated standards, overlapping investments, and a lack
            of coherent strategy. This Project came close to being
            cancelled during its life and has never enjoyed unimpeded
            progress. The political, security, and financial environment
            has been very difficult. However, the project did,
            ultimately, achieve significant improvements in the
            institutional structure of the sector and mobilize much
            needed investments in a rational way. This is attributable,
            in part, to the flexibility of most donors in the sector who
            were committed to adjusting the Projects (as feasible) to
            achieve the greatest good in the sector.
